title: How should I address an email to multiple people? - Quora

response.answer_text: It depends on who you’re emailing and why, the setting, and your relative standing with respect to them all. For example - if you’re replying to a question posed by your boss, who copied a bunch of other people…address your boss (e.g. “Good question, Bob”)If you’re originating the email, you can start with something along the lines of “Hi, all” or “Everyone” or something along those lines. If the recipients are all men or all women, you can even start with “Hello Ladies” or “Hi Gents,” although I suppose you run the risk here that someone might find a way to take offense.If you’re replying to a question posed to a group of people then you might dispense with an address altogether and just answer the question (“Bob asked about….” or “Part of the answer to Bob’s question is…”)If you’re way down on the totem pole and everyone else on the email is senior to you, it might be safest to go with something along the lines of “Hello everyone, and thanks for the question, Bob.”If it’s a bunch of your friends then you have greater latitude in how you start the email, but remember to take into account the sensitivities of all of recipients (e.g. “Yo bitches” might be good for your frat brothers, but maybe no if some have copied their wives, girlfriends, or mothers into the email chain)One more comment…. The greater the number of people copied on the email, the greater the number who you don’t know, and the higher the level of seniority of the highest-ranking person on the email (in the corporate world) the more careful you need to be with regards to formality, phrasing, content - and with spelling, capitalization, and punctuation. If it’s just between you and the others on your team, type it up and hit “send” - if your CEO is one of the recipients you likely don’t want to start your email with “Yo bitches” or to send a poorly written email that sounds like you consider your CEO to be one of your frat brothers.

Basically, there is no special rule for “an e-mail addressed to multiple people.” Just address it “to the people you’re writing the e-mail to,” denominated by a list of names or by descriptive groups, in whatever register¹ you have determined to be appropriate based on the relationship with the people and the type of communication. In fact, there’s no unified style for addressing e-mails, even business e-mails, the way there sort of is for business letters. “Dear” is frequently omitted in e-mails; I personally don’t use it and if I bother with a salutation line at all it’s usually just “[Name]:” Or in this case, “[Name] and [Name]:”. In less formal situations, it may be “Hi [Name]:”. Otherwise, however, you’d do this the same way as you would a letter with two addressees: to wit in most formal style (and some people do write their e-mails in the exact same format as a paper letter) “(Dear) Mr. Smith and Dr. Jones:”, “Mr. and Mrs. Smith:”; “Messrs² Jones and Smith:”, &c. If there are a lot of names (probably more than three at the least), “All:” or slightly less formally, “Everyone:”, may be acceptable. Sometimes a term like “Counsel:” (referring to multiple attorneys) or “Members of the Board:” or the like may also substitute for a list of names. In a slightly less formal style “(Dear/Hi) [First Name]” may be used; if there are multiple recipients, “Dear John and Mary” or the like. Whether it’s appropriate to address someone by first name alone has little to do with e-mail and varies with the context of the relationship. This is far more common in American English than in either British or international style, and it’s far more common now than it was a generation ago when I was young. This is not unusual, though, in correspondence between attorneys who know each other in a small Bar, intra-office correspondence, or otherwise in cases where the people would probably be on a first-name basis if they spoke in real life. Most people tend to write e-mail a step down in register from formal letters; this may extend to a greater willingness to use first names (or, perhaps, a greater reluctance to use first names alone in paper letters), but the long and the short of it is it still depends on the relationship. I would never use first-name only to correspond with someone I wasn’t already familiar with, though, like an out-of-county attorney with whom I’ve never worked before. It also goes without saying that it’s not normally appropriate to use first-names only when writing to someone who outranks you (except, perhaps, a direct supervisor). If I were addressing the Judge, for instance, the title and last name, or at a minimum the title, would be required. If this is not a business e-mail, just use whatever you would normally call the people: “Hi Sue and Johnny:” is fine. P.S. I join in Jeff Greene’s observations as well, to the effect that (1) there may be cases where the salutation is omitted entirely (after all, the person is being sent the e-mail, which implies it’s addressed to them)—in my case this is especially true for e-mails that are in a chain of close-in-time responses—and (2) you don’t normally mention people being cc’d on the email, only main recipients. It’s also not necessary to put “cc:” at the bottom of the message.  Note: ¹ “Register” and “style” are similar concepts; the former term is usually used to describe how formal a piece of language is. See also this answer. ² The classical plural of “Mr.” is messieurs or “Messrs.”; of “Mrs/Ms” mesdames or “Mmes.” These are rare even in formal American English these days, though I’ve still seen them occasionally in formal international style.

I think it depends if the email is asking a specific question of you (I. E. You are the specific person emailed and everyone else is C.C.) or the email is sent with a general question requesting input from everyone. If the email is specific to you, you must address and address it quickly, even if you don’t have an answer. If you do not have a specific answer because it is a problem you are working on, you should answer that you are aware of the issue and you are working to resolve it. The fact that the email was sent to you but with multiple parties suggests that the sender views it as an urgent matter. It may not be, but you cannot ignore the senders perception and responding punctually even if not completely should be reassuring to them. You also have to respond by using reply all. It would of course be much for the better if you can provide an answer that communicates what has and is being done, but in so doing just use a very factual tone. Go out of your way not to be defensive. If the sender is out of line with their email and CCing the friggin world try to get face time or get on the phone with them and talk it out. Many people get very brave and even bold behind an e-mail but in person are very kind, the medium of e-mail is not the best for everyone. If the email is a buckshot e-mail to a group asking for general input it is good to respond but only if you have something to offer. In these situations the sender is looking for help, if you have little to offer there is no point in responding. If someone else offers something that is helpful you can piggy back in their email and say something ‘yes I have done that also and I have found that to be helpful as well’ and acknowledge the senders contribution. If you do have something helpful to offer don’t hesitate to be the first to respond. The goal here is to be helpful.

That depends on who the group is in relation to you. I will do this when keeping people I work with, and those in the company we’re working for in the loop and updated as far as status goes. Usually, as in the above, it’s “To: All”. If I have to add something specifically to one person in an email to multiple people I will start with “All”, then skip a couple lines then “Bonny” or “Bonny, Clyde,” if to two people. If I am writing to several people well over my station in the company who barely know I exist, then I list each starting the list with those it is directly addressed to such as “J. Meloncamp, Director of Music” and keeping the list one name directly under the prior name. This also works for more formal situations. You may address people according to how you are sending it, too. The people in the BCC list are never named or titled, or mentioned in the email except to refer to them as them without indicating they got a copy. All those in the TO: and CC: lists should be acknowledged in some way, such as “All”. I do not use any formalities in salutations except Mr., Mrs., or their title such as “Senator Funnyname.” Sometimes, when there may be confusion as to why someone is getting an email as part of a list, I will include a brief one line reason why they got it at the bottom of the email. An example is “Mr. CEO: A status of the building security system.” Thanks for the request, Cory.

That would depend upon WHY you are sending it to multiple people. What do they have in common that led you to send it to all of them? Are they members of a previously established team that understands it is supposed to work together? If so, use the first sentences to clarify the team and its task. EXAMPLE: “Hello, fellow faculty of the Behavioral Science Dept. We need to finish the first draft of our APA accreditation report by January 31, and we need to get started next week. Click on this link to schedule our first meeting. In the meantime, visit this Google Document to review what the report has to cover.” Are they just a bunch of randomly selected possible opportunities for you (e.g., potential employers, potential book publishers)? Don’t emphasize that you are sending to so many people. If possible, customize each email. Suppose you would like a part-time teaching position and are sending out an email to deans and department chairs at 40 different colleges and universities in the metropolitan area. EXAMPLE: “Please keep me in mind for any part time teaching opportunities that might arise for the next academic term at Valley College. I taught an evening class for you (General Psychology) a couple of semesters ago. Since then, I have received my online instructor certification at your sister campus. I understand that in accordance with the new law, AB 705, you have restructured your Statistics class, and I am fully prepared to cover all that course now requires. As I recall, your favorite mode of communication is …”

Make sure your Subject line is short, clear and informative. For example: “Please review – Acme contract updates 09/09/2019”; or “Follow up to Acme meeting 09/09/2019 – FYI”. Only send it to the people who really must be included. Never simply “reply all” or include managers or team members associated with the topic but not specifically required for that communication or action. Be clear about what you want and who you want it from. If it is informational, put everyone on the “To” line. If you want action, put the people you want action from on the “To” line and cc the rest. Start the content of an email to multiple people by identifying who has to do something and what that is. Otherwise, they will all ignore the action item(s). To address a large group, I prefer to use “Hello”, “Team”, or some similar neutral heading that reinforces the business topic. If it is a more personal email, such as announcing the birth of a colleague’s child, use “Dear whomever (e.g., Dear Department of Transportation, Dear colleagues in the Bureau of Happiness) or just “Good Morning”. Some companies or parts of companies have specific rules. Keep in mind that some address line have to be broken out for people with titles (e.g., President Smith, Dr. Jones, Captain Ahab). If you have no personal or working relationship with the addressee, you might want to use Ms. or Mr. or the form of address expected in their country or culture. If there are such rules apply them as needed. Don’t hesitate to ask your management or colleagues for guidance.

How you format the receivers will make a bit of a difference. Blind copying means each will get their copy and not be aware of the others. Then constructing the contents as a memo should make it appear that the email was directed to them. Listing all recipients in the receiver box lets everyone know who you sent it to and includes their email addresses, too. Not necessarily good if someone fails to protect their contacts and contaminates everyone's emails… if your email is intended primarily for one person you can put them in the receiver section and cc the rest. Then you can personalize the email to the main recipient and everyone is supposed to understand that that was the primary audience. Now, if you are sending the same email to multiple people and you do not want to rewrite the email for each name you can copy the email and just enter each name and paste the copy and send. One copy and one email kind of personalized. When all else fails to appear to fit, I'd suggest you fall back on the "To Whom It May Concern" heading… im sure there are some folks out there who are a whole lot smarter than I who can give you better advise than I.

Awkward to do— I get them sometimes addressed to “All” or “Friends”, or “Everyone”. . I’m a professor so we use “Colleagues” a lot. I’m in a Fraternity , so “Brothers” works sometimes . If you are writing to your classmates , … well Dear “Classmates.” If its an informal letter, Yo, or Hi, or Hello works. If you are writing to teammates on a team…well you can guess. If you are writing to the School Board, try Dear Member of the No-Nonsense School Board. Is it a political Letter? Then try Dear Fellow Republicorats . Sometime you can try to be a bit funny such as Esteemed Teachers of ____School, “ How about Dudes and Dudettes? or “ “Belie-biers” “Fellow Eagle Scouts” Members of the Class of 2019. Sometimes I use the “ Dear” and sometimes not. It depends on how “friendly the letter is to be. I would be more likely too say Dear Teammates or Members of the Board. Sometimes it helps to address it like as formal Memo: To: Mel Blumberg, Chair, League of Distinguished Gentlemen From: Corey Haluska Subject: Question Regarding Addressing Multiple recipients to an e-mail. Refer to: My Memo of September 1, 2019 This is a follow-up on my memo of September 1, 2019 in which I …… Best Wishes, (signature and title under)

I think the important question is, are you addressing it to them collectively -and they will each see who else has received a copy - or are you sending the same information to each of them individually - and they don't all see who else is getting the email: depending on the situation, one of these is usually better than the other. If you are sending info to them, visibly to them all, then say so: "Dear All, I want you all to have this information and to know who else has received it." You'd probably go on to say something like "This can be circulated to colleagues and customers" or "This information is to please remain confidential to this group of people at the moment."If you're sending it to each of them, effectively privately, then either use a CRM to do an e-mailshot including e-mailmerge, so you can slot in their relevant salutation name, or put all the recipients on the BCC line (to protect their privacy), and simply begin with "Hello", "Good morning", "Hi", or whatever is most suitable.

To/ Reader I don’t think there is an agreed upon social etiquette, however there may be one that I just don’t notice exists. Personally, as I see e-mails as an evolution of traditional mail, I tend to write e-mails like slightly less formal letters. You may have realised, I do the same with Quora answers (well, most of the time). To multiple people, I would generally start with To/ All since I think that is the most clear and concise way of putting it. If I have a section that refers to just 1 member of the group, I tend to put my regular To/ (insert relevant person’s name here) and end that section by writing end of section. Other than that my e-mails don’t change. One section that is common amongst all of my emails is that I finish by typing my name, like a signature. I’ve found it’s a system that works for me. Michael

I am going to assume that you mean how to address the salutations instead of how to send to different email recipients. If so, then it really depends on the group of people you are sending to. If it is an informal group of people, such as friends, then you could put: Hi Everyone,Happy Friday Everyone,Hello All,If for a more formal group then you could include: Dear Members of the Committee,Hello Team:Hello Sales/Marketing/IT/etc Team:And of course, there is always the very simple way of addressing each person while addressing a small formal or informal group. For example: Dear John, Bob, and Sally:

To address and email multiple people you would have to keep it general. This is not the best idea of emailing a group. Normally, you need to make emails personal for it to interest the reader. Since I do not know the type of email you are wanting to send I will use me as an example. I run a business from home. I send a lot of emails in groups, however, I customize each one with their names. I do not send one at a time because I have to many. The size of my list it would be impossible to do and time-consuming. I have an autoresponder that gives me the ability to personalize all of them at one time. If you are interested in an autoresponder I’d be happy to help you out with an autoresponder. Otherwise to send the way you are talking about be sure to not use plural words like I hope you all have a great day. When you say all your readers will know it’s not just to them. I hope this helps. Susan J. Boston

It’s not a good practice to address many people in one email. It’s fine for me to make CC with 2–4 people but not more.I usually write all the names of people I communicate with.If people are from the same company I write “{company name} team”. I don’t like this approach addressing many people.The best variant is to segment and personalize your content and write directly to a person that you really need to write.For instance, you need to contact a company and to learn if they accept guest posts to your blog. Whom to connect with? Of course the editorial team, you needn’t contact the CEO if a company is big enough and has many departments. To find any email address on any domain → use an Email Finder.

I’m a construction project manager. I routinely— dozens of times a day— address emails to multiple people and most of the time multiple people working for different companies. These would be my boss (copy for record, it’s my job to do it, not his); the project manager and the site superintendent for the general contractor; the project manager and team leader for any subcontractors who may be involved; the project manager and senior project manager and design team leader for the customer (more copies for record); the lead and line architects who drew the prints; and the operations manager who will control the project after it is built and put into use. The salutation I use most frequently is “Team.” That’s what we are: a group of unrelated people who are united in the common objective of getting the damn thing built as fast as possible so we can all get paid and the ops manager has a usable facility once we are done.

If they are people of both genders, you can start “Dear Ladies & Gentlemen”. If it’s only females, “Dear Ladies,” If it’s only males, “Dear Gentlemen,” If you are addressing a specific group of people, such as a committee of both sexes, then “Dear Committee Members”, should suffice. If you are writing to a motley group of friends in an informal way, then “Dear Friends” should be acceptable. If it’s a limited number of people, say 2 or 3, you can start with the lady or ladies first. For example, “Dear Madam (or Mrs.) Lillian Tang, Mr. Adam Smith and Mr. John Rodrigues,” If it’s official, then you might start with the more senior person and end up with the least senior person. If it’s multiple people, more that 3, then you could list their name in the To section of your email in descending order of seniority. Your opening salutation could read : “Dear Madam/Dear Sir”.

If it’s an email you received that was issued to multiple people you do nothing unless there are instructions like the ones asking to confirm its received (in which case a simple ‘Confirmed. I receive it.’ is enough. If there are particular instructions for you then you follow them and reply if needed tot he person in private. If you are the one sending the email you need to be brief and concrete. Speak in 3th person or as impersonally as possible, say what you need to say, and issue instructions. VG of an invitation toa conference: ————- To all members of the production department.(WHO IS ADDRESSED TO) The Internal Inquisition Department (WHO ISSUES THIS) hereby invites all members to the collective burning of former accountant Karl-that-guy (THE ISSUE) on Thursday 35-March-2222 at 11am on the center in the parking lot (IFO LIKE WHEN AND WHERE). You may bring marshmallows. (EXTRA INFO) If you wish to participate in throwing the torches on the pire contact the materials department. No need to reply to this email (INSTRUCTIONS)

Depends on the circumstances. There are actually entire books written on etiquette. If you expect multiple people in the group to respond open with “Ladies and Gentlemen" or some other plural professional greeting, and write your email with items of mutual interest towards the top and anything specific for any one individual more towards the bottom. If it is something that everyone should be “kept in the loop" on then just write the email professionally and either CC: or BCC: everyone in the group. CC is “Carbon Copy” (because carbon paper is used to make duplicates of memos typed on a typewriter while being typed) and BCC is “Blind Carbon Copy" (meaning the BCC recipient will get a copy, but their copy won't have the email addresses of anyone else you sent the email to.

It depends on who the multiple people are. If it's formal, which is unlikely with an e-mail, I would start, "Dear Sirs and Mesdames". However, that level of formality is close to unknown in e-mails. If it's a business e-mail, you might wish to start with something like, "Hello Committee Members", "To all my employees", or something that means that they understand that they're each among the correct recipients. To friends, you might start, "Hi Friends!" To people who aren't necessarily friends but where it's not formal, you might choose, "Hi Everyone!" Where it is to not too many people, I'd say about five maximum, you could simply say, "Hi [name 1], [name 2], [name 3], etc.

It depends. Do you mean the salutation? An email could be created as a merged document to pop each person’s name into the correct field. Alternatively, you have to decide if you are letting the other people know who has been copied. There are blind cc’s. So, it could be correct to say: Dear Bob, Dear Mr. Jones, To all department heads of the ABC company, depending on how formal the communication is, whether you want everyone to know who has received, and whether hierarchy is important. An email sent to the entire company with details of the upcoming picnic is obviously quite different from an email regarding an upcoming termination. Scheduling a meeting between the CEO, CFO and Board of Directors regarding a company acquiring another involves a whole lot of care not only in addressing the importance of those involved, but also the sensitivity. When in doubt, consult similar emails sent in the past or the level of formality expressed in emails sent to you.

I think that depends on how many people count as “multiple”: If 4 or fewer, name them all (“Dear John, Krista, Sam, and George”)If more than 4, find another way to group them togetherWays to group people together: “Team”“Folks”“Everyone”Their job titles - particularly helpful for a diverse group (“Dear marketing team, sales team, and HR team”)Name the key person and generalize the remainder. For example, name the boss (“Dear Kelly and team”)The key in all addressing is to give respect to the people included, so that’s what you should keep in the back of your mind as you do this.

Original question: How should you address an email to multiple people? That depends on how many people and the reason for including them. If I am sending an email to a specific person, but other people need the information, then I will address the specific person. So if I send an email to the leader of a team at work but carbon copy the entire team, i may just address it to the team leader. As a funeral director, I sometimes send an obituary by email to multiple newspapers, so I just leave the greeting off because sometimes I do not know who will be handling it at any of the papers that day. Otherwise, Greetings, Greetings everyone, or something similar.

Usually, the email addresses of each of the multiple people are included in the To: bar. With this method, you can be sure each person received your email if each address is correct. If you are willing for the leader to relay your message to the others, the following method is a suggestion: If there is a leader of the multiple persons, address the email to the leader and then in the Subject bar you could name the subject and make reference to the group. Example for subject bar: Schedule for Clean Up Volunteers (Afternoon Group) Then in Text type a salutation to the leader and the group: Example: Mr Smith and Afternoon Volunteers Group, ( comma or colon) Below the salutation, write your message.

A2A It depends on context - I often start with “Dear colleagues”, even if it is to something like a customer services address. However just putting “Hello” as an opener would be enough when the recipients are strangers. If it is a social context you could try “Dear friends”, or “Hello everyone”; if it is informal, or part of a frequent chain of messages simply “Hi” would be sufficient, and many emails these days just start the message without any openers. In UK many of us feel obliged to put: “Dear… I hope you are well.” Even when it is to more than one person. I think this is left over from letter-writing days, when we were taught write letters, such as thank-you letters, starting them in this way. It does look a little odd in some emails! But it is perhaps more congenial to start with something that acknowledges the individual in some way. Sometimes I find myself going back and inserting a more personal greeting at the start, to show I am aware of the recipient as a person, and am not just thinking about my own reasons for sending the message, and barking it at them. A thing I have noticed is that emails may not be “read” in the same tone that they were “written”, so that a mood is conveyed that was not intended - accusation, for instance, or blame, and the message is interpreted in an unintended way, misunderstood. So it is probably a good idea to acknowledge, in some way, the person or people to whom you are writing. [Edit]. Oh. If you are communicating with your colleagues or superiors in one email, Messrs., Mmes., Mses., Mss. In the plural, Mr. becomes Messrs. (pronounced MESSers), and Mrs. becomes Mmes. (pronounced mayDAM). For the plural of the abbreviation Ms.,either Mses. or Mss. (both pronounced MIZZes) can be used. With a long list of names, it is better to use the plural forms of these titles. Messrs. Hamilton, Thorne, Bradley and Clarke addressed the gathering.The chair introduced Mmes. Thorington, Warner, Black and Sigurdson.Mses. Jacobson, Garner, Roberts and McGill founded the company.However, with two or three names, you should simply repeat the honorific. Mrs. Scarlet, Mrs. Peacock and Mrs. WhiteIf you are sending an email to a group of people who are your friends or family Hi Everyone!/Buddies!/Foodies!/Pals!/Bffs! Good morning clan!/brothers and sisters

I don’t think there’s a rule on addressing multiple people in an email. What I myself do is, if I’m sending one email to up to three people, I’ll name each one to make my email sound more personal (“Hello, John, Jane and Jill”). If I’m sending the email to more than three people, I’ll just refer to them as a group—”dear fam” or “dear neighbors”—or not address them at all, but go straight to my message. Naming each of the more than three recipients is not necessary, and is cumbersome.

Thank you for the A2A. If you are in contact with the people through an organization, such as a school, workplace, or volunteer organization, it is best to check with them to get their standards. Most places have some kind of protocol. In general, make sure you are blind copying everyone. This way you are not sharing email addresses - not everyone on the list will necessarily be ok with that. You also want to be sure, as the sender, you are using an appropriate account. For example, a school may want you to use an address they have assigned you, and not the one with the amusing name you chose for your gaming contacts. This is for your security as well. Within the email itself, if protocol doesn’t specify, it is good to use a group greeting - such as “Good morning, Classmates”, or “To all employees” or “Go Team! Game Day is Tuesday`” or something like that. A simple “Good morning” or “Greetings Everyone” will do.

It depends on the context and who the people are that you're writing to. You'll also need to think if it's an official or formal email or to a group that you personally know and you're writing not for work. Begin with “Dear” if it's a formal, work related or official email. Otherwise you can use “Hi all” or “Hi everyone” in any informal and not work related context. Going back to the work related, formal or official context, if you are writing to your customers, use “Dear customer”, if it's a shareholder use “Dear shareholder”, with colleagues “Dear colleagues”. You may have noticed that when you write to someone who is outside your company you use the single instead of the plural. This makes the reader feel that he's being personally addressed (although using their name individually would be the best option) rather than in a group. So far it's simple. There are some addressees where additional formality is required, such as when you write to Courts, nobility, royalty. Here you would prefer to write individual emails as you would need to use either “Sir” or “Madam”. And this is just touching the surface.

The first thing you have to do is set up a mailing list. You then give the mailing list either a number or name. On the list you put the email address of those you want to receive the mail. That done, write you email , on the send to line put the name of the list, this will then appear in the send to box, then press send, all in that list will receive the email, easier than typing out all the emails one at a time. It's used a lot in business, ok it's a bit long winded to write them all down, but you only have to do it once, if someone drops out of the group just delete their mail address from the list. If there are lots of names make two lists, (easier to edit names) I had my list by area.

If you want everyone's input, then just write Hi Bill, Ted, Donald, Ronald, etc. This makes it more personal and respectful such that, each person will eventually reply back you to. When writing Hi Everyone, You may not get a response immediately because others will assume someone will answer. Eventually after no one has replied, you may get that one person who replies just to reply. For the easily offended people with the skin thickness of toilet paper, if you write Hi All, They may take that as not having much respect for them and the offended ones will either not reply or reply in an unhelpful manner. It's kind of like saying “Can you pass me that pepper?” Versus “May I please have that pepper?” 99% of the time, saying may I will make the person jump up and immediately do things for you and feel bad for asking them using may I as if they were doing something wrong.

Depends on the group: Work colleaguesFormal: ColleaguesInformal: Hey, FolksFamily, multigenerationalLoved onesHey, idiotsTo those sharing genes with meFamily, same generationHey, idiotsYo!Oh, shit, we're getting old.FriendsDumb, dumber and dumbest (you choose)Cherished friendsThe point is, it depends on the mood you want to set, how close you are, and how many chances you're up for taking. You can get uproarious laughter, or fall flat on your face. An example from my career. One of the teams for which I was responsible came into a time critical operation 16 hours behind schedule due to delays in other parts of the bank. We were using a voice mail system for bank wide status updates. At the end of that shift, that team had made up the 16 hours, got their 8 done, and left their section 8 hours ahead on the timeline. 32 hours of work in 8. As I dictated their accomplishments, I wound it up with the words: “Congratulations to the Commercial Lending team for kicking ass.” Ten minutes later I was being lectured by my boss for my use of unprofessional language in bank wide communications when a beep interrupted the call announcing a new message. We mutually put each other on hold and listened. It turned out to be the Chairman of the Board, who had just left a bank wide message, congratulating my team for “some serious ass kicking".
